text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6MuteEnglish
from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello and welcome to 6MuteEnglish. I'm Alice.
And I'm Rob.
speaker: Rob

text: So Rob, did you have a part-time job while you were at university?
Ah yes, I worked in the student bar.
Did you learn anything from the experience?
speaker: Rob

text: I learned how to pull a decent pint.
speaker: Rob

text: Did you learn anything else?
Yes, I learned how to add up.
speaker: Rob

text: Didn't they teach you that at school?
I wasn't good at doing sums in my head, you know, mental arithmetic.
speaker: Rob

text: But I got pretty good at it as a barman.
They didn't have computerised cash registers in my day, you see?
Oh, I didn't realise you were that old, Rob.
Anyway, the subject of today's show is young business entrepreneurs.
So, can you answer this question?
How young were the founders of Facebook and Microsoft
speaker: Rob

text: when they first set up their companies?
Were they, hey, junior high school students?
B, high school students?
Or C, university students?
speaker: Alice

text: And Alice in case you think I don't know,
speaker: Rob

text: Facebook is an online social networking service
and Microsoft is a computer software company, okay?
Very good, well done.
Well, I'm going to say they were B, high school students.
Well, we'll find out if you chose the right answer later on in the programme.
But let's talk now about what drawbacks or disadvantages
speaker: Rob

text: there are for young entrepreneurs.
What do you think, Rob?
Well, I suppose one of the drawbacks of being young and your own boss
speaker: Rob

text: is that everyone who works for you is older than you.
Is that a drawback?
Well, let's consider a real case.
speaker: Rob

text: Young British entrepreneur Sulaman Sakhani started his first company when he was 17,
followed by another business shortly afterwards.
Then while studying chemistry at university,
he started his third company, an online version of the pound shop,
or dollar store in the US,
where everything in the shop is priced at one pound.
Let's listen to Sulaman Sakhani talking about his company.
I'm actually quite fortunate now, compared to what I was six months ago
speaker: INSERT

text: because now I've got two additional directors of Greyhair.
And it actually, commercial meetings are excellent now, you know?
But before that, I think I came across quite professional,
but you could still tell they were thinking in the back of their heads,
got kids sitting in front of me.
So young entrepreneur Sulaman Sakhani has got two Greyhair directors working with him now.
That's right
speaker: Alice

text: But how does having Greyhair executives on board help, Rob?
Well, executives are people who run a business,
and on board means being part of a team.
Well, to answer your question, Alice, they bring experience to the table.
I have a few Greyhairs, you know?
You could learn a lot from me.
Oh, I do, Rob, every day.
And if you bring something to the table,
speaker: bring something to the table

text: it means you provide something useful.
Well, what do you bring to the table, Rob?
Well, bad jokes, peanuts, crisps, cups of coffee, that sort of thing.
I was going to say a keen mind,
speaker: keen

text: in other words, a well-developed mind,
and great business acumen.
Oh, come on, you aren't going to say that.
You're right, I wasn't.
speaker: Acumen

text: Acumen means good judgment,
but don't worry, you have an abundant enthusiasm that makes up for it.
But moving on now, do you think that school prepared you well for working life?
No, not really. I studied Latin at school, and I don't use that much.
And maths, well, I never use trigonometry or calculus.
So I'm not sure how useful maths lessons were.
Mmm, yes, and you only learn to add up in the university bar after all.
Yes, but I'm very good at it.
And the point is that I've got a fantastic job now.
speaker: Alice

text: And if you're really interested in something,
you can always acquire or get the skills you don't have.
Let's listen to successful young entrepreneur, Jessica Rose,
talking about her experience.
She works with jewelry.
I didn't need all these previous skills and experience to go out there and start on my own
speaker: INSERT

text: When I first started, I had no business training whatsoever,
no jewelry training whatsoever.
But I kind of broke up one day and thought,
I'd really love to be a jewelry designer,
which is kind of a tricky position to be in because it's, you know,
a lot of people would say and did say,
well, you're, you know, your mad.
So Jessica Rose used her savings to learn jewelry making,
and then set up her own jewelry making business.
And despite setting out with no business experience and no jewelry training,
her enthusiasm for the article paid off.
speaker: Alice

text: And that means it was successful.
A bit like me.
Yes
speaker: Rob

text: Okay, I think it's time for the answer to today's quiz question.
I asked how young were the founders of Facebook and Microsoft
when they first set up their companies?
Were they a junior high school students,
b, high school students,
or c, university students?
I said b, high school students.
And you were wrong, I'm afraid.
speaker: Rob

text: Rob, sorry.
again
speaker: Alice

text: Yes.
speaker: Rob

text: Mark Zuckerberg and Bill Gates were both university students
when they started their companies.
Zuckerberg was studying at Harvard in the US when he launched Facebook in 2004.
And Bill Gates took a break from Harvard to launch Microsoft in 1976,
but never returned to his studies.
Yeah, both at Harvard, that's a coincidence.
I wonder if the bar there was any good.
Now, can we hear the words we learned today?
Yes, okay.
They are drawbacks, executives,
on board bring something to the table
speaker: Alice

text: keen, business acumen, acquire, paid off.
Thanks, Alice.
speaker: Alice

text: Well, that's the end of today's six minute English.
We hope you've enjoyed the new vocabulary that we brought to the table.
Very good.
Please don't ask again soon.
Bye-bye.
Bye.
